column17: On November 27, a police officer was shot while carrying out an arrest of a drug dealer in the village Tafahna al Azab in Gharbia.

The Egyptian opposition previously voiced protest against this visit due to the allegations of his involvement in the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

IS claimed that they killed or injured up to 20 military elements during the raids.

On Jan 15, in Rafah, close to Sadout checkpoint, suspected IS militants detonated an IED, killing several (unknown coded at low estimate of 3).

On Jan 22, the government announced the killing of 64 suspected IS militants and seven soldiers (including one officer) following several clashes targeting hideouts in Northern and Central Sinai. 142 militants were also arrested. Locations and dates of operations are unclear (coded as four battles occurring in January in Al Arish).
On Jan 16, in Rafah, IS militants clashed with Military Forces, and put fire to two ambulances and a hospital, injuring an unknown number of soldiers.

On Jan 17, in Al Qantara, dozens of people protested against the Government's decision to remove their homes. Security Forces intervened to disperse protesters.

On Jan 17, IS militants abducted a Christian police forensic expert while he was traveling in a taxi, North Sinai, close to Al Arish (geoprecision 2, coded as Al Arish). Police Forces clashed with the kidnappers, killing one and injuring 3. 2 policemen were also injured.
On Jan 17, Military Forces artillery shelled villages South of Sheikh Zuweiyid.
On Jan 17, Military Forces artillery shelled villages South West of Rafah.
On Jan 18, Military Forces' M60 artillery targeted areas close to Rafah hospital.
On January 18, one Egyptian, deported by Turkish authorities, was arrested in Cairo by Security Forces. His whereabouts are unknown.
On Jan 19, IS militants allegedly shot a soldier in Al Ahrash military camp, Rafah.
On Jan 19, Military Forces' artillery shelled areas close to Ahrash military camp.
On Jan 20, North of Al Barth, an IED exploded killing 2 and injuring one Bedouin Tarabin Tribe.
On Jan 20, Military Forces launched a bulldozing campaignin Al Manainah village, East of Al Arish, and in Al Matalafa and Al Wafaq villages, West of Rafah.
On Jan 20, Pro-Government Militias clashed with unidentified armed men North of Barth.
On Jan 20, Military Forces clashed with IS militants close to Al Arish, killing 14. They reportedly seized explosives. Other weapons were also found during a raid in Sinai Jabal Al Halal mountain.
On Jan 21, in Al Wifaq village, West of Rafah, IS militants clashed with Military Forces. Militants detonated an IED targeting a military bulldozer.
On Jan 21 (date unclear), Police Forces found and defused a bomb in a car in Qalyub, Banha-Mansoura road.

On Jan 21, near Giza pyramids, in Nazlat Al Samman village, a group of inhabitants staged a protest against the demolition of ""unauthorised buildings"". They tried to prevent bulldozers from entering the area. They reportedly clashed with Police Forces, who used tear gas and batons to disperse the protesters. Police Forces arrested 22 people.

On Jan 27, Military Air Forces targeted a hideout, allegedly killing several suspected IS militants, including 2 suspected IS leaders in North Sinai (location unknown, coded as Al Arish, fatalities unknown)

On Jan 27, Military drones shelled villages South of Sheikh Zuweiyid.

On Jan 29, an Egyptian photojournalist was also abducted by Police Forces at Cairo Airport. They were taken to an unknown location

On Jan 27, Military Forces' artillery targeted several villages, notably displaced houses in Al Rasm neighborhood, Balaa village, and in Tawil Al Amir village, West Rafah. They also reportedly bombed a house and led a bulldozing campaign West of Rafah on Jan 27-28.
On Jan 28, Military Forces' artillery targeted areas South of Sheikh Zuweiyid and Yamit village, West of Rafah.
On Jan 28, thousands of people from Qurajah village and around attended a military funeral, and chanted slogans against terrorism.

On Feb 1, Military Air Forces shelled an area close to Al Rasm School, in Rafah, and targeted Yamit and Balaa villages. (coded as 3 events - geolocation of Balaa coded as Rafah)

On Feb 1, Military Air Forces shelled an area close to Al Rasm School, in Rafah, and targeted Yamit and Balaa villages. (coded as 3 events - geolocation of Balaa coded as Rafah)

On Feb 1-2, in Al Warraq island, ""dozens"" of people reportedly blocked the entry of the island to construction workers and Military Forcs engineers to prevent the destruction of houses. (coded as 2 events)

On Feb 2 (or before, date unclear), after a police car ran over a woman in Aswan City, Karawar area, inhabitants blocked Sadat road to protest against the incident - blaming the police car for fleeing the zone after the incident. (coded as 2 events)

On Feb 2, Military Air Forces announced that they killed 8 IS militants, while targetting areas in the ""Western Desert"", in Fayyum governorate (location unclear, coded as Al Fayyum). They also allegedly destroyed vehicles and weapons. A number of militants were also arrested during the operations. Another source mentions the exchange of fire between militants and Military Forces.

On Feb 1-2, in Al Warraq island, ""dozens"" of people reportedly blocked the entry of the island to construction workers and Military Forces engineers to prevent the destruction of houses. (coded as 2 events)

column7: Journalists (Egypt); SPPA: Suspended Party Press Association
column17: On Feb 3, militants of the Suspended Party Press Association staged a protest at the Journalists Syndicate headquarters to demand the launching of the Association's website and the payment of their salaries.

On Feb 4-5 and Feb 9, Military Forces led a demining operation close to Al Ahrash military camp, and bulldozing campaigns in Yamit village (close to Rafah), Al Hawashi area and Sadra area (near Sheikh Zuweiyid), destroying houses and farms. They also reportedly destroyed a school in Yamit village. (coded as one event, location coded as Yamit).
On Feb 5 (or before), Military Forces raided a hideout in a ""remote area"" in Al Arish, killing 7 suspected IS militants, and reportedly seizing ammunition, weapons and explosives.

On Feb 5, IS militants ambushed a Baghdad police checkpoint, injuring 4 policemen, on the road between Luxor and Kharga towns, El Wadi El Gadid, in the Western Desert. (location coded as Kharga Oasis)

On Feb 6, unknown armed men attacked a military logistics convoy, killing and injuring an unknown number of soldiers, in Bir Gifgafa. (fatalities unknown). Gunmen also put fire to a number of bulldozers and military vehicles.
On Feb 7, three detainees, allegedly Muslim Brotherhood militants, accused of murdering a judge's son in 2014 in Mansoura, reportedly tortured to confess. They were later hanged in Alexandria.

On Feb 7, inhabitants from Al Idwah staged a protest against the hanging of 3 detainees the same day, accusing the regime of torturing them. They reportedly chanted slogans and carried photos of the detainees and of former President Morsi.
On Feb 8, Hafeez and Balaha families clashed over a revenge feud (motives unclear), killing two and injuring two in Qusiyah's Mosque, Assiut.

On Feb 10 (or before, date unclear), the relatives of political prisoner Abd el Fatah staged a protest in front of Tora prison, Cairo, after being denied five times their visitation rights. The same source mentions similar cases of denial of visitation rights for the last 10 days regarding other political prisoners.
On Feb 10 (or before, date unclear), IS militants detonated 2 IEDs, destroying a military bulldozer and a military vehicle, close to Al Arish Airport.
On Feb 10, in Beni Suef, in the Fourth neighborhood, a group of students from the Japanese school protested in front of the school against the rise of school fees.

On Feb 10, Military Forces' Artillery allegedly shelled and destroyed a tunnel linking Gaza to Egypt's Sinai, killing 9 Palestinians. Military Forces allegedly also used a poisonous gas in the tunnel. (location unknown, coded as Rafah)
On Feb 10, Military Forces bulldozed houses in Al Wahsha area, South of Sheikh Zuweiyid.
On Feb 10, Air Military Forces shelled areas around Al Rasm neighborhood, West of Rafah.
On Feb 11 (or before, date unclear), IS militants killed 3 soldiers and injured one, in Abu Shanar village, West of Rafah. They also detonated an IED, destroying a military bulldozer.
On Feb 12, IS militants attacked a military convoy, killing one soldier, between Al Mahdia checkpoint and Abou Farih checkpoint, South of Rafah.

On Feb 12, in Minya, Beni Mazar center, thousands of people participated in the funeral of a soldier who was killed during an ambush in Rafah, North Sinai. People protested against terrorism and chanted slogans.

On Feb 13, 3 Muslim Brotherhood militants, convicted of murdering Giza's Security Chief in 2013, were executed. Lawyers of the 3 militants claimed that they were tortured into confessing the crime. (location unknown, coded as Cairo)

On Feb 14, in Cairo, the Egyptian Parliament approved, with 485 votes out of 596 members, in principle proposed amendements allowing President Al Sissi's to run for two other mandates and to strenghten his control over the judiciary.
On Feb 14, Military Forces' Artillery shelled villages West and South of Rafah.
On Feb 14, Military Forces' Artillery shelled villages South of Sheikh Zuweiyid.

column16: El Fagr News; Egypt Independent; Al Shorouk
column17: On Feb 15, in Giza, in a square close to al-Istaqama mosque, an IED exploded and another one was defused by Police Forces. According to other sources, the explosion left 3 or 5 injured. The Interior Ministry blamed Muslim Brotherhood militants for the attack. A third IED was defused in Nahda Square. (coded as 2 events)

column16: El Fagr News; Egypt Independent; Al Shorouk
column17: On Feb 15, in Giza, in a square close to al-Istaqama mosque, an IED exploded and another one was defused by Police Forces. Depending on the source, the explosion left 3 or 5 injured. The Interior Ministry blamed Muslim Brotherhood militants for the attack. A third IED was defused in Nahda Square. (coded as 2 events)

On Feb 16, in North Sinai, IS militants attacked a Military checkpoint close to Al Arish Airport. 7 IS militants were reportedly killed and 15 soldiers were injured or killed. Another source mentions 3 soldiers killed. (unknown fatalities). Following the attack Military Forces allegedly cut communication services in the area.
On Feb 16, in Abu Hammad, a group of people participated in a military funeral of a soldier who was killed in North Sinai. People protested against terrorism.
On Feb 18, thousands of people attended a military funeral in Damanhur. They reportedly protested against terrorism, chanting slogans and carrying banners.

On Feb 18, in Cairo, close to Al Azhar mosque, Police Forces pursued a man, allegedly a Muslim Brotherhood militant suspected to be responsible for Feb 15's explosions in Giza. The militant detonated an IED, killing himself and three police officers. 3 civilians were also injured by the explosion.

On Feb 19 (or before, date unclear), in Al Arish, Military Forces clashed with unidentified armed men, during two military raids in Ubaidat and Abu Eita neighborhoods, killing 16 of them. Following clashes, the Army blocked roads from the eastern side of Al-Arish to Rafah and Sheikh Zuweiyid on Feb 19 - 20.

On Feb 19 (or on Feb 18), in Al Darb Al Ahmar neighborhood, Cairo, Police Forces discovered and defused an IED in an apartment. The apartment belonged to the militant who detonated an IED in the same area, killing himself and three police officers on Feb 18.
On Feb 20, in Cairo, nine defendants accused of being involved in the murder of Prosecutor General Hesham Berakat, in 2015, were executed. A ""number of them"" were allegedly tortured to confess.
On Feb 20 (or before), Military Forces destroyed 7 hideouts and killed 8 unidentified armed men in North Sinai. Location unknown, coded as Al Arish.

On Feb 22, four members of the Dostour Party, known to be opposed to the constitutional amendments that would extend President Sisi's mandate, were arrested by Police Forces at their homes in Cairo and Kom Ombo, Aswan governorate. Their whereabouts are unknown. (location coded as Cairo)

On Feb 23, in the morning, 8 people were arrested by Military Forces during raids at their homes, in Markaz Faqous (Sharkia governorate) and in Damanhur (Beheira governorate). Their whereabouts are unknown. (location coded as Damanhur)

Between Feb 24-25 and on Feb 28 (date unclear), Military Forces led bulldozing campaigns in areas West of Al Arish and South and West of Rafah. (location coded as Rafah)
On Feb 26, during a funeral, inhabitants in Kafr as Sawaqi protested against the government. [size=no report]

On Feb 26-27-28, Egyptian and Israeli Military Air Forces and artillery shelled areas around Rafah, Sheikh Zuweiyid and Al Arish, targeting IS positions. No fatalities were reported. (coded as 3 events)
On Feb 26, in Al Arish, unidentified armed men stole a car belonging to the Agriculture Ministry.

On Feb 26-27-28, Egyptian and Israeli Military Air Forces and artillery shelled areas around Rafah, Sheikh Zuweiyid and Al Arish, targeting IS positions. No fatalities were reported. (coded as 3 events)

On Feb 26-27-28, Egyptian and Israeli Military Air Forces and artillery shelled areas around Rafah, Sheikh Zuweiyid and Al Arish, targeting IS positions. No fatalities reported. (coded as 3 events)

On Feb 28, following a train accident which left 22 dead in Ramses Station, Cairo, one man staged a protest alone in Tahrir Square to demand the resignation of President Al Sisi. He was arrested by Police Forces along with another man who was taking pictures of him. Their whereabouts are unknown.
On Feb 28, in Al Rasm area, West of Rafah, clashes between unidentified armed men were reported. No fatalities reported.
On March 1st, in Santa Police Station, Tanta, militant Islam Khalil was forcibly disappeared by Police Forces after being ordered to be released by a criminal court.
On March 1, in the morning, 7 people were arrested by Military Forces during raids at their homes, in Abu Kabir and in neighbouring villages. Their whereabouts are unknown.

On March 1st, in Al Idwah village, a number of people protested against the government and Military Forces, following the train accident in Cairo which killed 22 and injured many. Protesters reportedly held pictures of former President Morsi. [size=no report]

On March 1st, in Imbabah, in front of Rahman Mosque, a group of people protested against the government, following Ramses station train accident in Cairo which left 22 dead and many injured. Police Forces intervened and arrested ""many"" [size=no report]

On March 1, people protested in Alexandria, Behera (Damanhur), Fayoum and Gharbia governorates, against the government and military forces, following Ramses station train accident in Cairo which left 22 dead and many injured. Police intervened and arrested 190 people across the four locations. Madamasr reports at least 70 arrested nationwide. [size=no report]

On March 1st, Israeli Military Air Forces shelled villages South of Sheikh Zuweiyid.

On March 1st, in Cairo, in front of Al Fath Mosque, Ramses, a group of people protested against the government, following a train accident which left 22 dead and many injured. Police Forces interfered to disperse protesters, and more than 21 of them were reportedly arrested, among which children under 18. Their whereabouts are unknown. Number of protesters unknown. [size=no report]
On March 3 (or before, date unclear), in Sheikh Zuweiyid, Military Forces allegedly shot at a students' bus, killing one student and injuring another.
On March 4, two brothers of opposition member and tv host Moataz Matar, their wives and children were abducted by Police Forces in Nasr city. The day before, police also raided his mother's house.

column16: Al Masry Al Youm (Egypt); Daily News (Egypt)
column17: Week of March 4, clashes between military forces and suspected IS militants in North and Central Sinai left 46 militants and 3 soldiers killed. Military forces also destroyed explosives and weapons, shelled hideouts and arrested 100 militants. Coded as four events (two in Al Arish for North Sinai, two in al Hasna for Central Sinai to cover at least two days of fighting during the week in each area) with fatalities spread throughout.

column16: Al Masry Al Youm (Egypt); Daily News (Egypt)
column17: Week of March 4, clashes between military forces and suspected IS militants in North and Central Sinai left 46 militants and 3 soldiers killed. Military forces also destroyed explosives and weapons, shelled hideouts and arrested 100 militants. On March 6, in the evening, in Cairo and in ""other governorates"" (unclear where), thousands of protesters blocked streets in protest against military rule in Egypt. (coded as Cairo, geoprecision 3). [size=thousands]

On March 6 (or before, unclear), in Nasr City, a group of workers staged a protest in front of Al-Nasr General Contracting Company to demand the payment of their salaries and dues. On March 7, Police Forces raided the houses of 7 of them, and arrested them. [size=no report]

On March 6, in Giza, Police Forces arrested trans woman and militant Malak al-Kashif at her home. She had taken part in the protests in Cairo following the deadly train accident in Ramses Station several days before. Her whereabouts are unknown. Another transgender was also reportedly arrested end of Feb for taking part in the protests.

On March 7, in Giza, Police Forces killed 7 suspected Hasam militants during two operations. During the first operation, 3 suspected militants, in a truck, were carrying explosives, disguised as electricity workers. During the second, Police Forces raided an apartment and killed 4. One police officer was injured during the clashes. Police Forces reportedly seized explosives and weapons. (coded as 2 events, fatalities spread)

On March 7, in Giza, Police Forces killed 7 suspected Hasam militants during two operations. During the first operation, 3 suspected militants, in a truck, were carrying explosives, disguised as electricity workers. During the second, Police Forces raided an apartment and killed 4. One police officer was injured during the clashes. Police Forces reportedly seized explosives and weapons. (coded as 2 events, fatalities spread)
On March 7, Military Forces announced the destruction of 9 entrances to three Sinai tunnels at the border. They also reportedly destroyed explosives and vehicles. (location unknown coded as Rafah)
On March 7, in North Sinai, one soldier was killed and two injured during an attack by suspected IS militants. (location unknown, coded as Al Arish)

On March 7, East of Yamit village, West of Rafah, Military Forces' Artillery shelled houses of internally displaced people. Military Forces also launched a bulldozing campaign in the area and in Balaa village.

On March 9, in Rafah, suspected IS militants detonated an IED, injuring 5 soldiers and damaging 2 military vehicles.

On March 9 (or before, unclear), in Giza, in front of the National Heart Institute, a number of doctors and medical employees protested against the dismissal of the hospital director Gamal Shaaban. [size=no report]
On March 9, near Ahrash military camp, Military Forces' Artillery shelled an area close to Abu Agwa Mosque.
On March 9, in Sheikh Zuweiyid, Military Forces clashed with suspected IS militants. Two soldiers were killed.
On March 9, in Al Arish, Military Forces clashed with suspected IS militants. Three soldiers were killed and two injured. Another report mentions 4 injured.

column16: Egyptian Commission for Rights and Freedoms; Madamasr
column17: On March 10, in a public hospital, trans woman and LGBT figure Malak al-Kashif, arrested on March 6 after she took part in protests following Ramses station train accident, was reportedly sexually assaulted and forced to anal examination by employees. (location unclear, coded as Giza, as the source mentions she was detained in Haram Police Station, Giza).

On March 10, in Cairo, a Palestinian was allegedly abducted by Egyptian Security Forces. On March 17, his family in Gaza received a phonecall from Gaza Security Forces that his body was discovered, with evidence of torture, near the Suez Canal.
On March 11, near Al Arish airport, IS militants detonated an IED, targeting Military Forces. One soldier was killed.
Between March 11-13, Military Forces bulldozed displaced people's houses in Tawil Al Amir and Al Masoura villages, North and South of Rafah.
On March 11, Military Air Forces bombed areas South of Sheikh Zuweiyid.
On March 12, East of Al Arish, suspected IS militants clashed with Military Forces, killing qt least 2 of them and injuring 2 (some sources report 3 fatalities).
On March 13, close to Rafah, near Sadout village, IS militants detonated an IED, destroying a military vehicle.
On March 16, Police Forces arrested a female student in Zagazig. Her whereabouts are unknown.

On March 17, Police Forces raided houses in Diyard Najm and other neighbouring villages, and arrested 3 men. Their whereabouts are unknown. Several people were also allegedly arrested the day before in Abou Baker village.

On March 18, IS militants' rockets damaged a tank and a military bulldozer, close to Tawil area, East of Bilaa village. Number of soldiers injured unknown. Militants reportedly seized weapons. (coded as Rafah)

On March 18 (or before, unclear), in Qanatir Prison Hospital, actor Iman al-Helw and trans man Hossam Ahmed were forced to undergo ""invasive sexual examinations"". They have been detained for taking part in protests following the Ramses station's deadly train accident.
On March 19, Military Forces clashed with suspected IS militants in Sheikh Zuweiyid.
On March 19, Military Forces destroyed houses and a mosque in Tawil Al Amir village, West of Rafah.
On March 21, suspected IS militants killed two soldiers, including one officer, in Central Sinai. (location unknown, coded as Al Hasna)
On March 21, IS militants fired missiles at the army, damaging a vehicle in Mouhagarah area, East of Bilaa village, Rafah.

On March 21, close to Al Arish airport, IS militants detonated an IED on a military patrol, killing at least one officer and injuring several. Another source mentions 2 soldiers killed by the explosion.

On March 22, in Al Warraq, thousands of inhabitants protested against the arrest of 3 men from the island, and against the government's alleged intent to displace them and seize their lands [size=thousands]
On March 22 or 23 (date unclear), Egyptian and Israeli Military Air Forces shelled areas near and West of Rafah and near Sheikh Zuweiyid. (coded as 2 events)
On March 22 or 23 (date unclear), Egyptian and Israeli Military Air Forces shelled areas near and West of Rafah and near Sheikh Zuweiyid. (coded as 2 events)

On March 24, in the industrial area of Al Arish, South of Al Arish, IS militants carried out two separate IED attacks on military convoys. 2 officers, one soldier killed in the first attack, also destroying a bulldozer and a Humvee. Four soldiers killed in the second attack. Number of injured unknown. (coded as 2 events)
On March 24 and/or on March 26 (date unclear), Military Forces' Artillery shelled displaced houses in Al Rasm area, West of Rafah. They also led a bulldozing campaign in the area.
On March 25, in Central Sinai, on the way to Gifgafa area, IS militants shot a soldier.

On March 25 or on March 26 (date unclear), on the Km 4 road, South of Bir Al Abd, Central Sinai, unidentified armed men attacked a vehicle composed of civilians working for the army and soldiers. At least one soldier and two civilians were killed, and 10 wounded. Another source mentions 17 killed. (fatalities coded as 3)

column16: Rassd; Al Ahram; FJ Portal; Al Akhbar (Egypt)
column17: On March 25, in Asyut, Al Azhar University campus, female students staged a protest following rumors stating that a female student was raped and killed near the school. Police intervened to disperse the protesters. One professor and one student, accused of spreading the rumor, were later arrested. [size=no report]
On March 25, in front of Zagagig Cultural Centre, tens of students from Sharqia high schools organized a sit-in to demand changes in the education program. [size=tens]
On March 26, IS militants' M60 destroyed a military bulldozer in Mouhajarah area, close to Rafah.

On March 26, in Al Mahallah Al Kubra, a group of workers of Ghazal 6 factory and Ghazal 7 factory, Misr Spinning and Weaving Company, started a protest against the non-payment of their salaries. [size=no report]
On March 26 (or March 25, unclear), in the main streets of Al Ashmunin, tens of female students marched to denounce the corruption in the education system. [size=tens]
On March 27, 2 soldiers were killed by an IED detonated by suspected IS militants in Dakmah Kalih area, South of Rafah.

On March 27, in Abu Kabir, during a Police raid, a police officer assaulted a lawyer as a result of an altercation following his refusal to let her see the Attorney General's permission for an arrest warrant. Report mentions that she was left severely injured.
On March 28, IS militants detonated an IED South of Sheikh Zuweiyid, between Abu Jahini checkpoint and Abu Sorour checkpoint. Unclear if casualties.
On March 28, Military Air Forces shelled areas close to Al Arish Airport, South of Al Arish.

On March 29, in Al Warraq, Al Warraq inhabitants marched to protest against the government's displacement plan and to demand the release of those arrested for demonstrating for similar reason a week before. [size=no report]
On March 30, IS militants detonated an IED on a military vehicle, killing three soldiers. They reportedly seized weapons.
On March 31, two Bedouins working with Military Forces were killed by the explosion of an IED in Sinai. (location unknown, coded as Al Arish)

On March 31, in Cairo, dozens of workers from the National Cement Company staged a protest in front of the Ministry of Public Works Sector against their working conditions. They demanded an increase of their incentives. [size=dozens]
On April 1, South of Qina (location unclear) two families clashed in the streets using firearms for unclear reason. Report mentions one person killed and another one injured.
On April 6, in Suez, nurses in Suez Hospital for Health Insurance protested after one of their colleagues was allegedly assaulted by the family of a patient. [size=no report]

column16: Al Masry Al Youm (Egypt); Daily News (Egypt); Egypt Window
column17: On April 7, near Al Nozha Police Station in Cairo, several unidentified armed men attacked a police patrol, killing 2 of them and injuring two others.
On April 8, IS militants attacked soldiers West of Al Arish, allegedly killing and injuring 7, and seizing weapons.(unknown fatalities coded as 3)
On April 8, according to an IS source, Military Air Forces allegedly targeted an area South of Sheikh Zuweiyid, killing two women and three children.
On April 9, close to Al Arish, between Jibal Al Saada and Al Ras Al Ahmar, IS militants detonated an IED, destroying a tank and a military vehicle, killing an unknown number. (unknown fatalities)

On April 9, in Sheikh Zuweiyid, in the market area, an IS suicide bomber detonated his suicide belt close to a police patrol. He killed 4 policemen and three civilians, among which a 6 year old. 26 others were injured.
On April 9, one soldier was killed and another injured by an IED detonated by IS militants targeting an armored vehicle in Rafah, near Abu Shanar checkpoint.
On April 9, a soldier was shot by IS militants at Al Masoura checkpoint, close to Rafah.
On April 11, policemen raided a hideout in a farm, in Kalyoubia governorate, and reportedly killed 6 suspected Hasam militants. They also seized weapons. (location unknown coded as Banha).

column16: Amaq; Al Gomhurriah; Nashir; Al Masry Al Youm (Egypt)
column17: On April 12, suspected IS militants attacked policemen at Ayn Moussa checkpoint, 30 km from Ahmed Hamdy Tunnel. 4 policemen were injured. 2 militants were killed. (location unclear, other reports mention that the attack took place in South Sinai - coded as Suez).

column16: Nile News TV; Al Bawaba; Daily News (Egypt)
column17: On April 12, government announced the killing of 11 suspected IS militants in Al Arish, during a raid in Abouita. Military Forces also seized weapons.
On April 13, South of Sheikh Zuweiyid, IS militants destroyed a military vehicle at Masalah checkpoint, allegedly injuring and killing an unknown number of soldiers. [unknown fatalities ]

On April 13, in a village in Sohag, a group of Muslims assaulted a priest and a Coptic Christian close to Saint Karaas Church, demanding to shut down the ""unlicensed"" church. Another source mentions 3 people injured. Security Forces were allegedly present but did not interfere. The church was later closed for ""security reasons"". [size=no report]

On April 14 (or April 13), in Al Midan area, West of Al Arish, IS militants detonated an IED, destroying a military vehicle, killing and injuring an unknown number. (unknown fatalities coded at low estimate of 3)

On April 14, in Abou Al Arag village, South of Sheikh Zuweiyid, suspected IS militants detonated an IED on a military vehicle, killing and injuring an unknown number (unknown fatalities coded at low estimate of 3).
On April 15, in Qouz Ghanem area, West of Rafah, suspected IS militants detonated an IED, killing and injuring an unknown number of soldiers (unknown fatalities).
On April 15, Egyptian and Israeli Military Air Forces targeted Al Mouqataa and Al Touma villages, South of Al Arish.
On April 15, Military Forces Artillery targeted Tawil Al Amir area North of Rafah, and areas close to Gaza borders.

On April 16, Parliament approved constitutional amendments reinforcing the role of the military and allowing President Al Sissi to stay in power until 2030. Populations will later vote on a constitutional referendum to enact these amendments.

On April 17, lawyer Abdelhamid Jabir was arrested by police forces while attending a judicial session related to the renewed detention of his daughter. His whereabouts are unknown. (location unclear, coded as Cairo, geoprecision 3).

On April 20, in Nast City, District N5, during the second day of the three-day referendum, activist Ahmed Badawy, several minutes after he started holding a sign saying ""no to the amendments of the Constitution"", was arrested by Police Forces. His whereabouts are unknown.
On April 20, Military Air Forces bombed several areas South of Sheikh Zuweiyid.
On April 22, one Christian was killed by unidentified armed men on the road between Al Arish and Qantra.
On April 22, Military Air Forces bombed and destroyed an IDP's house in an area West of Rafah, East of Balaa.

On April 22, the government announced that the amendments of the Constitution approved a week prior by the Parliament were aso accepted by a referendum. These amendments will be implemented. They allow current President Al Sissi to stay in power until 2030, while giving more power to the military.

On April 22, suspected IS militants detonated an IED on a military vehicle composed of pro-government militia members, close to El Agra village. The explosion killed and injured an unknown number. (unknown fatalities coded at low estimate of 3)

On April 22 (or before, unclear), in Alexandria, while traveling in a microbus, journalist Abeer Al Safati was arrested by policemen. Police stopped the car and required passengers to vote for the referendum but she refused. Her whereabouts remain unknown.

On April 23 (or after, date unclear), IS militants detonated an IED on a military vehicle on the international road, West of Al Arish, killing and injuring an unknown number. (fatalities coded at low estimate of 3)

On April 26, a group of inhabitants in Al Idwah marched in the streets to demand the departure of current President Al Sissi. Protesters were reportedly carrying pictures of former President Morsi. [size=no report]

On April 28, close to Ahrash military camp in North Sinai, an Islamic State's IED exploded while soldiers were trying to defuse it. Number of injured and killed unknown; unknown fatalities coded as 3.
On April 28, in Midan area, West of Al Arish, IS militants detonated an IED on a military vehicle, killing and injuring an unknown number. (fatalities unknown, coded at low estimate of 3)

On April 28, in 10th of Ramadan city, Fricool Company's workers, on strike for the ninth day, clashed with a group of unidentified men who were preventing them from entering the company's headquarters to continue their demonstration. Police forces interfered later to disperse rioters. [size=no report]
On April 30, Military Forces's Artillery targeted and destroyed houses in Balaa village, West of Rafah.

On May 1, following an IED explosion detonated by suspected IS militants, killing 2 soldiers in Al Arish the same day, Military Forces' Artillery targeted IDPs' houses in Tawil Al Amir village, North of Rafah, and in Al Mansoura village, South of Rafah, destroying several homes.
On May 2, Military Air Forces targeted buildings in Rafiah village, South of Rafah.

On May 2 (or May 1st), during a military campaign in Tawil Al Amir area and Safah area, West of Rafah, Military Forces clashed with suspected IS militants. Three soldiers were allegedly killed and six injured.
On May 3, Military Air Forces targeted an area West of Muqataah village, South of Rafah.
On May 5,in Helwan, two families clashed following a land dispute. Three were injured by gunfire.

On May 6, IS militants detonated an IED on the road between Sheikh Zuweiyid and Kharuba, close to  Al Abidat ambush, near Sheikh Zuweiyid, destroying a military device. An unknown number was killed and injured. (fatalities unknown, coded at low estimate of 3)

On May 7, tens of inhabitants from Al Kanayis village, Kafr ad dawar district, in Behera staged a protest in front of the Governorate Office following shortage of drinking water. [size=tens] (location unclear, coded as Damanhur, geoprecision 3)

column16: Al Masry Al Youm (Egypt); El Fagr News
column17: On May 7, in Cairo, in Sada El-Balad news website's headquarters, journalists were assaulted by film-maker El Sobki and a number of his security guards following an alleged dispute between the newspaper and the film-maker. 3 journalists were injured and several goods damaged.

On May 7, South of Al Arish, South of Al Hafn area, suspected IS militants detonated an IED killing and injuring an unknown number of soldiers.  Another report mentions 7 killed and injured during two attacks in North Sinai on May 7.
On May 7, unidentified armed men clashed with policemen in Sharm El Sheikh, killing one policeman and injuring an unknown number.
On May 8, the Egyptian air force bombed an area West of Al Muqataal village, South of Rafah.
On May 8, the Egyptian air force bombed several times areas close to Al Arish airport.
On May 8, the Egyptian air force bombed IDPs' houses East of Rafah, West of Balaa village.
On 05 September, 2019, Egyptian military forces destroyed a house in Bir Al-Abd in an air strike killing some thought to suspected of belonging to IS. Unknown fatalities.
On May 9, the Egyptian air force bombed empty buildings in Al Muqataal village, South of Rafah.
On 05 September, 2019, IS fighters injured a number of Egyptian military personnel in an attack using heavy machine guns and rocket propelled grenades in Touma south of Sheikh Zuweiyid.

column16: AFP; Egypt Independent; Al Ahram; Egypt Today
column17: On 05 September, 2019, Egyptian police forces killed 6 IS militants in Bahariya Oasis.
On May 11, IS militants detonated an explosive device resulting in the destruction of an army tank. No deaths were reported.

On May 13-14, political activist Ahmed Maher, founder of April 6 Youth Movement was arrested at his home South of Cairo, in Giza, and labour rights lawyer Haytham Mohamdeen, was arrested at a police station in Cairo's suburbs, both over charges of ""aiding a terrorist group"". (location coded as Cairo geoprecision 2)
On May 14, suspected IS militants shot a civilian accused of collaborating with the army in Al Arish, in Malik Al Masamir neighbourhood.
On May 14, unidentified armed men shot at a young girl in Sheikh Zuweiyid, injuring her leg.

On May 15 (or May 16), an employee from Oum al Rada village, Damietta, died, after being arrested by police forces a few days ago. He was allegedly forced by policemen while in prison to ""take pills"", allegedly resulting in his death. (location unclear, coded as Damietta, geoprecision 3)

column16: Twitter; Facebook; Al Masry Al Youm (Egypt)
column17: On May 16, Military Forces announced that 47 suspected IS militants and five soldiers were killed and 4 wounded during clashes in Sinai. 300 explosives were defused and many weapons seized during the operations. Military Air Forces reportedly claimed the destruction of 30 hideouts. (location of clashes unknown- coded as Al Arish geoprecision 3).
On May 16, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in Al Zawariat village and Lafitat village, close to Sheikh Zuweiyid. (coded as Sheikh Zuweiyid, geoprecision 2)
On May 17, in North Sinai, an officer was killed by unidentified armed men (unclear how, coded as armed clash). (location unknown, coded as Al Arish geoprecision 3)

On May 18, close to As Sabil village, West of Al Arish, suspected IS militants detonated 2 IEDs on a brigade and on a military vehicle. An unknown number of soldiers were killed and injured by the explosions. [fatalities unknown]

On May 19, close to the Pyramids of Giza, near the new museum, an IED's explosion targeting a tourist bus injured 17 people, among which South African and Egyptian tourists. The attack was not claimed by any group but the government accused Hasam militants.
On May 19, a military drone bombed a house in Al Lafitat village, South of Sheikh Zuweiyid, North Sinai.

On May 20, following the explosion targeting a tourist bus close to the Pyramids of Giza the day before, police forces killed 12 suspected Hasam militants close to Cairo during raids in 6th October area and Al Shorouk neighbourhood. Weapons and explosives were seized. (coded as 2 events, fatalities spread)

On May 20, following the explosion targeting a tourist bus close to the Pyramids of Giza the day before, police forces killed 12 suspected Hasam militants close to Cairo during raids in 6th October area and Al Shorouk neighbourhood. Weapons and explosives were seized. (coded as 2 events, fatalities spread)

column16: Twitter; Al Masrawi (Egypt); Al Masry Al Youm (Egypt)
column17: On May 21, in Mansoura, in front of the Monument to the Unknown Soldier, dozens of female students staged a protest against the failure of a new electronic system in charge of evaluating students. Police Forces interfered, assaulted several students. Several students were also arrested. [size=dozens]

On May 21, following an attack on a tourist bus in Cairo two days earlier, Military Forces clashed and killed 16 suspected IS militants during raids in Al Arish. Two hideouts were reportedly destroyed.

On May 21, South of Al Arish, close to Lafn ambush, IS militants detonated IEDs against a military bulldozer, a tank and a foot patrol. IS IED attacks on 21 May reportedly killed 6 people and injured 20 in Al Arish and Rafah, and were split across three events.
On May 21, IS militants's RPG killed a guard in Al Ahrash military camp, West of Rafah.

On May 21, military forces clashed with IS militants in Al Mahdiyah village, South of Rafah, close to Abu Farih ambush. An unknown number of soldiers left killed and injured, and a tank was destroyed. Another source mentions that IS attacks on May 21 led to at least 6 soldiers killed and 20 injured. (fatalities unclear, coded at low estimate 3)

On May 21, IS militants detonated IEDs on groups of soldiers near Abou Ziraa and Falougah ambush, south and west of Rafah, and on the international road to Rafah close to Sadout. IS IED attacks on 21 May reportedly killed 6 people and injured 20 in Al Arish and Rafah, and were split across three events.

On May 21, in Rafah, close to As Saha military camp, IS militants detonated an IED on a military vehicle, killing and injuring an unknown number of soldiers. IS IED attacks on 21 May reportedly killed 6 people and injured 20 in Al Arish and Rafah, and were split across three events.
On May 21, in Al Barth, suspected IS militants detonated an IED next to Al Malahi Mosque, on a group of Sinai Tribal Union militants, killing one.
On May 21, military forces's artillery targeted suspected IS positions, East of Abu Jahini village, South of Sheikh Zuweiyid.

On May 21, hundreds of students marched in Alexandria to protest against the new electronic system in charge of evaluating students. Students also protested against the Minister of Education, demanding his departure. [size=hundreds]
On May 21, in Kafr ad Dawwar, dozens of students staged a protest in front of the City council,against the level of their French exam, judged too difficult. [size=dozens]

On May 21 (or before, unclear), female secondary students protested in Kafr az Zayyit against the failure of the new electronic system in charge of evaluating students. Police forces allegedly interfered and arrested a number of girls. [size=no report]

On May 21, students demonstrated in various parts of Ismailia governorate to protest against the failure of the new electronic system in charge of evaluating students. Police forces allegedly interfered and arrested a number of protesters. (locations unclear, coded as Ismailia, geoprecision 3) [size=no report]

On May 21, in Es Sinbillawin, dozens of female students staged a protest against the failure of a new electronic system in charge of evaluating students. Police allegedly interfered to disperse ""peacefully"" protesters.[size=dozens]

On May 21, in Mit Ghamr, dozens of female students staged a protest against the failure of a new electronic system in charge of evaluating students. Police allegedly interfered to disperse ""peacefully"" protesters.[size=dozens]

On May 21, in Dikirnis, dozens of female students staged a protest in front of the Education Administration against the failure of a new electronic system in charge of evaluating students. Police allegedly interfered to disperse ""peacefully"" protesters. [size=dozens]
On May 22, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in Al Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuweiyid. No fatalities reported.
On May 22, in Al Arish, a suspected IS landmine exploded, killing one soldier and injuring 4 others.
On May 22, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in Al Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuweiyid. No fatalities reported.
On May 22, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in Al Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuweiyid. No fatalities reported.
On May 23, close to Al Kharafin ambush, East of Sheikh Zuweiyid, IS militants shot a soldier. Militants also detonated an IED which destroyed a military vehicle.
On May 23, close to Balaa, West of Rafah, IS militants detonated an IED, killing and injuring an unknown number of soldiers. (fatalities unknown, coded at low estimate 3)
On May 25, Military Air Forces targeting suspected IS positions bombed empty buildings in Al Muqataal village, Az Zuhayr village and Al Lafitat village. (coded as 3 events)
On May 25, South of Cairo, workers from Sugar Fayyoum Company protested against corruption and demanded better working conditions. [size=no report]
On May 25, Military Air Forces targeting suspected IS positions bombed empty buildings in Al Muqataal village, Az Zuhayr village and Al Lafitat village. (coded as 3 events)
On May 25, Military Air Forces targeting suspected IS positions bombed empty buildings in Al Muqataal village, Az Zuhayr village and Al Lafitat village. (coded as 3 events)
On May 26, in North Sinai 4 officers and 5 soldiers were killed during a mission in Al Hasna by suspected IS militants. (circumstances unclear, coded as Armed clash).
On May 27, East of Al Arish, IS militants attacked a group of soldiers in Al Manayna ambush, killing one and injuring an unknown number.
On May 27 (or before, unclear), Military Forces's Artillery targeted houses in Al Jurah village, killing 5 civilians and injuring 8 others, among which children.
On May 28, West of Rafah, IS militants detonated an IED killing one soldier and injuring others.
On May 28, Military Air Forces bombed several suspected IS positions in Shabbanah village, South of Rafah.
On May 28, Military Air Forces bombed several suspected IS positions in El Agra, South of Rafah.
On May 29, Military Air Forces bombed displaced houses and landfields in at Tumah village, South of Sheikh Zuweiyid.

Between May 28-May 31, Military Forces demolished Karnak City Village's buildings and around. They forcibly displaced inhabitants, allegedly using tear gas and bullets. In Nagaa Abou Asba village, electricity and water were cut, and at least 100 inhabitants were arrested.

On May 30, workers of Minya Cement Company staged a protest in fornt of the Company's headquarters, to demand better working conditions. A number of them reportedly started a hunger strike. (location uncertain coded as Minya geoprecision 2)[size=no report]
On May 30, workers of Al Gomhouriya newspaper staged a protest in front of Dar El Tahrir For Printing and Publishing, in Abdeen, Cairo, to demand better working conditions. [size=no report]

Between May 28-May 31, Military Forces demolished Karnak City Village's buildings and around. They forcibly displaced inhabitants, allegedly using tear gas and bullets. In Nagaa Abou Asba village, electricity and water were cut, and at least 100 inhabitants were arrested. On May 31, a number of inhabitants opposed to their displacement demonstrated, burning tires. Clashes with military forces were reported, leaving an unknown number injured. (coded as 4 events) [size=no report]
On June 4, IS militants allegedly attacked a military truck near Meliz airbase, Bir Gifgafa, Central Sinai.
On June 4, IEDs detonated by IS militants allegedly destroyed 2 military vehicles East of Al Arish, in Maydan area.

column6: Police Forces of Egypt (2014-) Prison Guards
column17: On June 5 (or June 4, unclear), in Wadi Natrun prison, a prisoner aged 22, arrested when he was 16 years old, died under torture.

column16: Madamasr; Al Dostor; FJ Portal; Twitter
column17: On June 5, following IS attacks the same day on checkpoints near Al Arish, military forces launched a raid in a building in Abou Eittah area, Al Masaid district, in Al Arish, and allegedly killed 14 suspected IS militants. They also seized weapons and explosives.

In the morning of June 5, IS militants attacked four security checkpoints near Al Arish (Algaz, Gouda, Alzakhroukiya, and Batal 14). The main attack was at Batal 14 checkpoint in El Sebil village. Sources report that between 10 and 14, including soldiers and militants, were killed.
On June 6, unidentified armed men raided Mazar village and abducted 8 inhabitants from their homes and a paramedic.
On June 7, eight IS militants hiding ""in an olive grove"" were killed in Al Abour area, south of Al Arish.
On June 8, West of Rafah, Military Air Forces bombed IDPs' houses in Balaa village and targeted Quz Gha0nim area, South of Rafah. Another report mentions militants firing at planes (unclear).
On June 8, four IS militants were killed during a raid in Al Arish. Police seized automatic rifles, bombs and explosive belts.
On June 8, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in Al Muqataah.
On 06 September, 2019, workers held a sit in at their company headquarters in Tanta, Egypt demanding the fulfilment of their contracts [size=no report].
On June 9, military forces use bulldozers to destroy homes in Sakadrah village, close to Sheikh Zuweiyid. 'Many' inhabitants were also arrested.
On June 9, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions around Al Arish Airport.

On June 9 (or June 10), at the Kharafin checkpoint, located east of Sheikh Zuweiyid, an IED was detonated by IS militants. An unknown number of soldiers were killed and injured (coded at lowest estimate 3).

On June 9, in Hihya, thousands of people joined the funerals of a prisoner allegedly dead due to medical negligence in the Hihya police station. Demonstrators protested against police forces. [size=thousands]
On June 9, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in Shabbanah village, South of Rafah.
On June 10, an IED was detonated by IS militants, damaging a military bulldozer south of the Al Arish airport.
On June 10 (or June 11), artillery shootings, allegedly by military forces, was reported in Al Rasm area, west of Rafah. The artillery reportedly caused a fire.
On June 11, Military Air Forces bombed buildings, targeting suspected IS positions in Balaa village, West of Rafah.

On 11 June 2019, police forces arrested Ibrahim Ezz El-Din, researcher on the right to housing at the Egyptian Commission for Rights and Freedoms (ECRF), a human rights law firm based in Cairo. Following arrest the individual was held for at least 167 days.

On June 12, Ibrahim Ezz El-Din, researcher at the Egyptian Commission for Rights and Freedoms was detained by security forces on his way home in Muqattam, Cairo. Security forces have denied having custody of the El-Din and his where about remain unknown.
On June 12, in the Al Midan area, west of Al Arish, IS militants detonated an IED, destroying a military vehicle. At least 5 soldiers and one policeman were injured by the explosion.
On June 12, at an IS checkpoint, near Sebeka village, in the Bir al Abd area, IS militants abducted up to 10 civilians, including 2 lawyers. IS later released 3 abductees.

column9: Labour Group (Egypt); Military Forces of Egypt (2014-)
column17: On June 12, in Mazar, IS militants abducted 4 Sebika Salt Factory workers suspected of working with the army. IS also seized 2 vehicles.
On June 14, Military Air Forces targeted suspected IS positions in Sheikh Zuweiyid.
On June 14, Military Air Forces targeted suspected IS positions in Rafah.
On June 15, a soldier was shot and killed by IS militants at Al Masourah checkpoint, Rafah.
On June 15, in Al Midan area, west of Al Arish, IS militants detonated an IED, killing and injuring 9 soldiers. (fatalities unclear, coded as 4)
On June 16 (and/or on June 17), in the Al Ahrash area, Military forces' M60 targeted homes of IDPs. A military bulldozing campaign was also launched in Siaha area, North of Balaa village.
On June 17, in Tura, Scorpion Prison, around 130 prisoners started a hunger strike against ""inhumane conditions and denial of family visits"". [size=130]

column16: HRW; FJ Portal; Amnesty International; Twitter
column17: On June 17, in Eastern Cairo, during a trial, prisoner and former President Mohammed Morsi died ""after he fell into a coma while in a cage in a courtroom"". Several NGOs have accused the government of denying him access to basic medical care and being responsible for his death.
On June 17, IS militants shot and killed a soldier at the Kafrashin checkpoint, South of Rafah.
On 17 June 2019, during the night, suspected IS militants abducted a sheikh and his daughter from a farm located between Bir Al Abd and Al Rouda.

On June 18-19, in Idwah, birthplace of former President Mohammed Morsi, security forces prevented inhabitants from gathering and entering Al Makawi Mosque following Morsi's death on June 17. Protesters demanded an investigation on the conditions of Morsi's death, on June 17. Police also raided houses, among which houses of Morsi's family. 10 inhabitants were arrested, allegedly including Morsi's brother. [size=no report] (coded as 2 events)

On June 18-19, in Idwah, birthplace of former President Mohammed Morsi, security forces prevented inhabitants from gathering and from entering Al Makawi Mosque following Morsi's death on June 17. Protesters demanded an investigation on the conditions of Morsi's death, on June 17. Police also raided houses, among which houses of Morsi's family. 10 inhabitants were arrested, allegedly including Morsi's brother. [size=no report] (coded as 2 events)
On June 19, South of Al Mazar village and East of Bir Al Abd, Military Forces raided and set fire to a number of homes of IDPs. They also arrested an unknown number of inhabitants.
On June 19, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in Balaa village, West of Rafah.
On June 20, in El Fitat village, Military Air Forces targeted suspected IS positions. Militants allegedly fired back at military planes.
On June 20, west of Al Midan area and west of Al Arish, IS militants detonated an IED killing and injuring an unknown number of soldiers. (fatalities coded at lowest estimate 3).
On June 20, in the Ahrash area, close to IDPs' houses, military forces' artillery targeted suspected IS positions.
On June 21, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in the Shabbanah area.
On June 21, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in At Tumah village.
On June 21, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in El Agra.

column9: Military Forces of Egypt (2014-); Labour Group (Egypt)
column17: On June 22, close to Al Arish airport, IS militants attacked construction workers working with the army, killing 4 and injuring 6. Militants also burned two vehicles.
On June 22, following IS's attack on construction workers the same day, Military Air Forces bombed areas on the international road, close to Al Arish airport.

On June 24, overnight, in southwest Al Arish, IS militants attacked 3 military and police checkpoints (on a bridge over Arish Valley, at the entrance of a cemetery south of the town, and close to Rifai Square, in front of North Sinai Social Solidarity Directorate building security station), allegedly killing one officer and six conscripts, and injuring 11 others. Military forces killed 3 militants. Another militant died when he activated his explosive vest. Military forces reportedly seized explosive vests. However, according to IS sources, 20 soldiers were injured or killed during the attacks.

On June 24, following several coordinated IS attacks in Al Arish, close to a new bus station where one of the attacks took place, a military vehicle fired mistakenly at a car driven by local residents. One man was killed and another one suffering severe burn wounds got ""his arm amputated"" at the Hospital. A woman was also shot in the leg. Another source mentions other civilians allegedly injured by the army, notably a university student.
On June 25, in Yamit village, military forces destroyed a house. No fatalities reported.
On June 25, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions close to Al Arish airport.
On June 26, at night, Military Air Forces launched a missile which hit two homes West of Al Arish, near Kilo 17 checkpoint, killing 9 civilians belonging to the Bedouin Sawarka tribe.
On June 26, at Sadout checkpoint, West of Rafah, IS militants detonated an IED, killing and injuring an unknown number of soldiers. (fatalities coded at low estimate 3)
On June 26, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in areas located southeast of Sheikh Zuweiyid.
On June 26, IS militants attacked two military checkpoints in Al Arish, along the Arish-Qantara International Road and in Masaeed neighborhood, close to Mar Mina church. Two soldiers were injured.
On June 27, Military Forces' Artillery targeted several villages South of Al Arish.
On June 27, IS militants detonated an IED on a military bulldozer close to Al Arish airport, killing and injuring an unknown number of soldiers. (fatalities coded at low estimate 3)

On June 28, south of Al Arish, IS militants abducted and killed three civilians, accused of being ""spies"" for the army.
On June 28, in Rafah, Military Air Forces bombed empty buildings in several neighborhoods.

On June 29, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in Ash Shallaq, Qabr Umayr and El Kharouba villages. (coded as 3 events)
On June 29, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in El Fitat village.
On June 29, in Rafah, Military Forces' Artillery fired at houses in Al Rasm and Shouyoukh neighborhoods.

On June 29, between Bir Al Abd and Baghdad village, in Central Sinai, suspected IS militants detonated IEDS on 3 electric towers providing electricity for 4 cement factories. Explosions led to power outage.
On June 29, 2 Bedouins from Tarabin tribe and from Ayaydah tribe were abducted by suspected IS militants in North Sinai. (location unknown, coded as Al Arish geoprecision 3).
On June 29, Military Air Forces bombed suspected IS positions in Ash Shallaq, Qabr Umayr and El Kharouba villages. (coded as 3 events)
On June 30, North of Sheikh Zuweiyid, military forces' artillery opened fire on several areas.

column17: On October 17, 2019, in Cairo, human rights lawyer Amr Imam was arbitrarily arrested by police officers and held an unknown location for 24 hours before being sent to Tura Prison. Days before his arrest he announced that he was planning on doing a hunger strike to protest police brutality, torture, and arbitrary arrests and enforced disappearances.

On October 19, 2019, in the village of Abu Al Araj south of Sheikh Zuweiyid, Egyptian Military Forces carried out a drone strike that struck two homes belonging to civilians, leaving 4 dead and 11 injured.

On or before October 19, 2019, at a checkpoint near Al Mahdiyah, and IED was detonated on an armored vehicle belonging to the Egyptian Military Forces, leaving an unknown number of people dead and wounded.

On or before October 19, 2019, in the village of Al Mahdiyah, armed clashes began between the Egyptian Military Forces and gunmen belonging to an unidentified armed group after gunmen attacked a Military sweeping campaign in the village, resulting in an unknown number of fatalities.

Police allegedly forced 22 confessions. [size=dozens]

On October 21, 2019, east of Bir Al Abd [coded at geoprecision 2], Islamic State militants detonated explosive devices on two Hummers belonging to the Egyptian Military Forces, killing and injuring an unknown number of soldiers on board. column17: On October 21, 2019, in the Scorpion Prison of the Tura Prison complex, prison guards tortured a large number of detainees who had recently gone on a hunger strike to protest conditions in the prison. On October 22, 2019, west of Abu Al Araj [coded at geoprecision 2], Egyptian Military Forces targeted Islamic State militants with a drone strike, killing eight people in total, though it is unknown how many of the eight were militants.

In response to this attack, numerous families moved from Abu Al Araj to Sheikh Zuweiyid where it is considered safer from militants.

On or before October 25, 2019, in Sheikh Zuweiyid and Al Arish, Egyptian Military Forces launched a total of four airstrikes; the number of airstrikes in each city is unknown.

The Egyptian military forces did not report any fatalities or injuries.

On 8 December 2019, Islamic State militants carried out a series of attacks on military and police checkpoints and other security targets in Rafah (Rafah, North Sinai) and Sheikh Zuweiyid (Rafah, North Sinai), and eyewitnesses heard dozens of explosions. In Rafah, (North Sinai), one police and two others were injured, while one militants was killed and an unknown number of militants were injured. A total of 4 soldiers were killed in these attacks, meaning that three fatalities are assigned to Sheikh Zuweiyid.

On 8 December 2019, Islamic State militants carried out a series of attacks on military and police checkpoints and other security targets in Rafah (Rafah, North Sinai) and Sheikh Zuweiyid (Rafah, North Sinai), and eyewitnesses heard dozens of explosions. In Rafah, (North Sinai), one police and two others were injured, while one militants was killed and an unknown number of militants were injured. A total of 4 soldiers were killed in these attacks, meaning that three fatalities are assigned to Sheikh Zuweiyid.

On 8 December 2019, Egyptian military forces launched retaliatory airstrikes against Islamic State militants east of Sheikh Zuweiyid (Rafah, North Sinai), after Islamic State militants launched a series of attacks against Egyptian military forces earlier that morning. The Egyptian military forces did not report any fatalities or injuries.

On 9 December 2019, Islamic State militants targeted a tank with an IED west of Al Arish (Al Arish, North Sinai), killing and wounding an unknown number of Egyptian soldiers. Unknown number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 9 and December 2019, Islamic State militants targeted a vehicle belonging to the Egyptian military forces with an IED near Al Fallujah checkpoint west of Rafah (Rafah, North Sinai), killing and injuring an unknown number of Egyptian soldiers. Unknown number of fatalities coded as 3.

An unknown number of soldiers were killed and injured, while there is no information about fatalities of militants. Unknown number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 9 December, 2019, Islamic State militants targeted a tractor belonging to the Egyptian military forces south of Rafah (Rafah, North Sinai), killing an unknown number of soldiers on board. Unknown number of fatalities coded as 3.

On 9 December 2019, Islamic State militants targeted a vehicle belonging to the Egyptian military forces with an IED near Sheikh Zuweiyid (Rafah, North Sinai), causing no injuries or fatalities as soldiers were able to escape. Islamic State militants set the vehicle on fire afterwards.
On or before 10 December 2019, Egyptian military forces shelled the Al Tufaha area east of Bir Al-Abd (Bir Al-Abd, North Sinai), and one shell fell on a civilian home.

column16: The Observatory for the Protection of Human Rights Defenders
column17: On 10 December 2019, a board member of the Egyptian Commission for Rights and Freedoms (ECRF) was arrested and tortured by police in Nasr City (Cairo). The victim was arrested at a police checkpoint when he refused to enter the password for his phone to be searched and then brought to a police station and tortured until he revealed the password.

On 15 December 2019, protesters organizing under the name Ahrar Al Buhaira protested at night in Damanhur (Damanhur, Behera), chanting slogans criticizing the military for arbitrary detentions, poor human rights record, and for the deteriorating economic conditions in Egypt. [size=no report].

On 16 December, 2019, Egyptian Police Forces used tear gas, water cannons, and batons to break up a sit-in by 10 factory workers in Port Said (Al-Munakh, Port Said), causing an unknown number of injuries. Police arrested approximately 170 protesters. The factory workers were protesting the decision to change their entry gate, asserting that the change of entry will cause delays attending work on time [size=hundreds].

column6: Police Forces of Egypt (2014-) Prison Guards
column17: On 16 December, 2019, families of detainees stated that detainees arrested during the September 20 protests have been subjected to psychological and physical torture by prison guards in Zagazig Prison (Zaqaziq, Sharkia).

On or before 17 December, 2019, Egyptian Police Forces arrested 25 students from Al-Azhar University in Nasr Ciy (Nasr City, Cairo), with no report on the reason for the arrests.

On 17 December, 2019, Islamic State militants targeted a vehicle belonging to the Egyptian Military Forces in Sharifat, a village east of Al Arish (Al Arish, North Sinai), causing no fatalities or injuries.

On or before 22 December 2019, protesters gathered at night in Damanhur (Damanhur, Behera) to protest against the treatment of Uighur Muslims in China as well as of conditions in Egypt, such as treatment of detainees, poor economic conditions, and enforced disappearances [size=no report].

On or before 22 December 2019, Islamic State militants targeted the Egyptian Military Forces with three mortar shells at a military checkpoint south of Rafah (Rafah, North Sinai), leading to an unknown number of fatalities and injuries.

column17: On 23 December 2019, clashes broke out between prison administration and approximately 26 former Egyptian military officers who are now prisoners in Haykestep region of El Obour City (Kalyoubia), which resulted in the prison administration calling in Egyptian Special Forces to end the clashes. On or before 24 December 2019, an unidentified armed group shelled a village west of Sheikh Zuweiyid (Rafah, North Sinai), killing one civilian and injuring others.

On or before 26 December 2019, militants belonging to an unidentified armed group attacked a village south of Sheikh Zuweiyid (Rafah, North Sinai) and kidnapped two civilians. The attack left two other civilians injured.

column16: Madamasr; Xinhua; Masr Alarabia; AP; Al Bawaba; AFP; FJ Portal; Egypt Today; Rassd
column17: On 14 January 2020, Egyptian Police Forces raided the office of Anadolu Agency, a Turkish media outlet in Cairo (Al-Wayli, Cairo), cutting off the Internet, turning off security cameras, and arresting four employees, three of which were Egyptian citizens and one of which is a Turkish citizen. The arrests came at a time when Egypt is carrying out increasing arrests against lawyers, activists, and journalists, and when tensions between Turkey and Egypt have grown over the support for opposing sides in Libya.

On 14 January 2020, clashes broke out between Islamic State militants and members of the Egyptian Military Forces south of Rafah (Rafah, North Sinai) when members of both groups were attempting to reach the site of a recent plane crash in which an Egyptian fighter pilot died. The circumstances of the crash are unclear, with both BBC Monitoring and The New Arab reporting that the plane may have been shot down by the Islamic State, though they have not claimed responsibility for the attack.
On 15 January 2020, Egyptian Military Forces fired a shell at a transport vehicle in Bir Al-Abd (Bir Al-Abd, North Sinai), killing one civilian and injuring a second civilian who were in the car.

On 17 January 2020, Egyptian Police Forces arrested dozens of activists and journalists in Cairo, particularly around Tahrir, Ramses, and Talaat Harb Squares. Police Forces also set up numerous checkpoints in Cairo to search civilians identifications and social media accounts, and conducted raids on rented homes near Tahrir Square. This activity comes days prior to the ninth anniversary of the January 25 Revolution.
From 17 January 2020 to 20 January 2020, Egyptian Police Forces carried out a campaign of arbitrary arrests in downtown Cairo (Al Wayli, Cairo), with arrestees primarily consisting of young men.

column6: Police Forces of Egypt (2014-) Prison Guards
column17: As reported on 21 January 2020, students held as prisoners in Banha Public Prison (Banha, Kalyoubia) were stripped of their clothing and beaten while taking their final semester exams. A letter also leaked describing the torture of prisoners; they were beaten by guards, electrocuted, and had faeces smeared on their faces and put in their mouths.

On 21 January 2020, Islamic State militants killed the former director of the Supply Department days after kidnapping him from Bir Al-Abd (Bir Al-Abd, North Sinai). The Islamic State claims that they killed him because he was collaborating with Egyptian security forces.

Protesters denounced the Ministry of Health and called for measures to improve the work environment and decrease administrative abuse of Egyptian doctors, specifically the practice of arbitrarily sending doctors to work in other provinces without warning or extra compensation [size=no report].

Injuries and fatalities of Islamic State militants are unknown.

On or before 26 January 2020, Egyptian Military Forces and Islamic State militants engaged in armed clashes in Rafah (Rafah, North Sinai). A sergeant and two soldiers were killed and five others wounded in clashes in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweiyid (fatalities split across two events).

On or before 26 January 2020, Egyptian Military Forces and Islamic State militants engaged in armed clashes in Sheikh Zuweiyid (Rafah, North Sinai). A sergeant and two soldiers were killed and five others wounded in clashes in Rafah and Sheikh Zuweiyid (fatalities split across two events).

Between 3 February 2020 and 4 February 2020, Islamic State militants attacked Egyptian Military Forces south of Sheikh Zuweiyid (Rafah, North Sinai), killing seven soldiers and injuring eight others. However, multiple sources reported that a single IED attack on 3 February killed 7 soldiers, and therefore the total number of deaths over the two days of attacks is not certain. The militants used snipers, a number of IEDs, and heavy weapons to attack Egyptian forces. In addition to the casualties inflicted on soldiers, the Islamic State militants destroyed a tank and damaged a tank, a bulldozer, and the vehicle carrier [fatalities coded as 7 for 4 February 2020].

On 26 September 2020, hundreds of protesters gathered in Saqr Quraysh neighborhood in Al Nozha (Cairo), protesting the demolition of buildings to make room for a new road and bridge in their area. On 30 September 2020, Egyptian military forces conducted air strikes and artillery shelling targeting Islamic State militants in Rafah (Rafah, North Sinai) after an attack earlier that morning by the Islamic State. Resulting fatalities or injuries were not reported.

On 1 October 2020, Egyptian military forces conducted air strikes and artillery shelling targeting Islamic State militants in Rafah (Rafah, North Sinai) as part of a campaign targeting the Islamic State in the area. Resulting fatalities or injuries were not reported.

Around 1 October 2020 (beginning of month), Egyptian military forces reclaimed villages in Bir Al-Abd (Bir Al-Abd, North Sinai) that had been held by the Islamic State since July 2020. The villages included Qatiyah, Iqtiyah, Raba, Marih, and Al Janayan. There were no reports on fatalities or injuries incurred in the operation of expelling IS militants from the area.

On 3 October 2020, two Muslim men bullied a Coptic child at a wedding, prompting other Copts in attendance to confront the two, leading to a violent confrontation that left the Muslims injured in Samalut (Markz Samalut, Menia). [size=at least 3]

On 4 October 2020, Islamic State militants and Egyptian military forces engaged in armed clashes after the Islamic State attacked the military forces in Bir Al-Abd (Bir Al-Abd, North Sinai), killing 2 Egyptian soldiers. Whether or not there were fatalities sustained by the Islamic State was not reported.

On 4 October 2020, Islamic State militants targeted a bulldozer belonging to the Egyptian military forces with heavy weapons at the Kharafin checkpoint south of Sheikh Zuweiyid (Rafah, North Sinai), damaging the bulldozer.
Around 4 October 2020 (as reported), Egyptian military forces detonated approximately 30 homes belonging to Egyptian civilians in the villages of Yamit, Balaa, and Al Ahrash (Rafah, North Sinai).

Around 4 October 2020 (as reported), Egyptian military forces opened fire on Egyptian IDPs after allowing them to return to their homes in Al Janayan in Bir Al-Abd (Bir Al-Abd, North Sinai), which had been taken over by the Islamic State in July 2020. Resulting fatalities and injuries were not reported.
Around 4 October 2020 (as reported), an Egyptian soldier was injured after a bomb exploded in Bir Al-Abd (Bir Al-Abd, North Sinai). The group responsible for the bomb was not identified.

There were no reports on resulting fatalities or injuries from the shelling.

On 5 October 2020, thousands of civilians who were displaced from their homes when the Islamic state took over their villages in July 2020 protested against the Egyptian military forces at the edge of their villages in Bir Al-Abd (Bir Al-Abd, North Sinai), calling for the military to allow them to return to their homes. [size=thousands]

On 5 October 2020, a Muslim man previously involved in an incident of religious violence on 3 October 2020 retaliated against local Copts by beating a Coptic man and his son with a hose in Samalut (Markz Samalut, Menia), which caused them to fall off the bike they were on. The same day, a group of Muslims attacked local Copts and damaged their properties in Samalut after escalating tensions in the previous two days following the incident of religious violence at a wedding. Two other women were also killed the same day in another village in Bir Al-Abd. They were among the internally displaced people who had just returned to their houses in areas under ISIS's control.

Police in Serengeti District, Mara Region, have reportedly killed a man suspected to have been among the poachers who killed a rhino in the Serengeti National Park. A source said suspects arrested in connection with the rhino killing were taken to Mugumu Central Police Station where they were reportedly tortured.

Police here yesterday engaged in running battles with the University of Dodoma (Udom) students boycotting classes to demand for payment of their allowances. The law enforcers had to use tear gas to prevent the students from staging a procession, but the youngsters managed to circumvent the police net and marched to Dodoma town and gathered at Nyerere Square.

Ethnic clashes erupted between Sonjo and Maasai communities in which one Maasai member was killed.

Fresh ethnic clashes have erupted between Sonjo and Maasai tribes, in Ngorongoro District, Arusha Region [northern Tanzania], claiming the life of one person and injuring three others. Mgongo Mageri and Loirien Magaiduru villages are the most affected by the clashes revolving on land disputes.

During an attempt to break up a commotion related to witchcraft killings, the police shot two people in Musoma Town.

Four people suspected to be the robbers who escaped from Kagongwa Police Post after killing two policemen, have been lynched to death by an angry mob. Two further suspects are being treated for serious injuries after their beatings by villagers.

Police were yesterday forced to use tear gas to disperse passengers, led by students, who were clashing with commuter bus operators. Bus operators staged a strike over the bus fare claiming that the Sh300 they pay every time a bus leaves the main bus terminal was very high.

Five people were feared dead yesterday following a clash between residents of Madale in Dar es Salaam and security forces of a court broker on the outskirts of the city. The chairman of Wazo Ward, Mr Deodatus Kamugisha, said over 50 security men riding in a fleet of about five mini-buses had gone to the village to demolish houses on disputed land following a court order.On arrival at the village, said Mr Kamugisha, angry villagers who were armed descended on the security men and started to attack them with machetes, iron bars and other crude weapons.

PC Joseph was killed on Wednesday when a team of law enforcers were dispatched to the area to arrest people engaged in bhang farming.However, upon seeing a troop of policemen, the villagers attacked and killed one officer and injuring another.

A primary school boy identified as Noel Simon, 13, was taking care of the family livestock when bandits pounced on him. Accounts from the area said the gang strangled the boy to death before driving away with 700 head of cattle and 200 goats.

Thousands of passengers travelling to and from Dar es Salaam, Morogoro, Coast, Tanga, Kilimanjaro and Arusha regions as well as neighbouring Kenya were yesterday stranded for about three hours after irate villagers blocked the Chalinze - Segera road following the killing of a child by a speeding vehicle.

A policeman stationed at Gibaso police post at Nyarukoba Ward in Musoma is alleged to have shot dead a villager. It was alleged that the policeman reportedly shot the villager on allegations that he was a criminal on the run.
